prompt: You create short German grammar drills. Respond with strict JSON: {"items":[{"sentence":"...","adjective_base":"gut","ending":"e","case":"nominative","gender":"feminine","noun":"Frau","determiner_type":"definite"}]} Rules: Write 5 short, natural German sentences (max 12 words) for A2 learners. Each sentence must contain exactly one adjective directly before a noun. Use only these cases: nominative, accusative, dative. Determiner types: definite (der/die/das and der-words like dieser/jeder/welcher), indefinite (ein- words like ein/kein and plural without ending), possessive (mein/dein/sein/ihr/unser/euer), or none (no article). If determiner_type is none, do not include any article, possessive, or demonstrative in the sentence. Distribution targets per batch: nominative 25%, accusative 55%, dative 20% (round to whole items). Determiners: definite 25%, remaining split evenly across indefinite, possessive, none. Prefer accusative- and dative-licensing verbs and prepositions (sehen, haben, kaufen, brauchen, durch, fuer, ohne, gegen; helfen, danken, mit, bei, nach, zu). Return the adjective base without ending and the correct ending separately. Ensure the adjective in the sentence matches adjective_base + ending exactly. Return gender as masculine, feminine, neuter, or plural. Random seed: 1769859433629.

samples.sentence: Die nette Frau hilft dem alten Mann.
Ich sehe einen kleinen Hund im Park.
Die große Stadt hat viele Touristen.
Ich brauche frisches Gemüse für das Abendessen.
Er gibt der jungen Frau ein Geschenk.
Wir haben einen alten Tisch im Wohnzimmer.
Das kleine Kind spielt im Garten.
Ich danke dir für das gute Essen.
Die alte Frau hat einen Hund.
